channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Singular Offense of the Mass Grave
item.description: Violent loss is even more devastating when the dead are disposed of without identification. When Russians pull out in Ukraine, they leave a trail of anonymous death.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Numbers, not names, on makeshift grave markers near Izium last week.

item.title: Europe’s Energy Crisis Forces Factories to Go Dark
item.description: Manufacturers are furloughing workers and shutting down lines because they can’t pay the gas and electric charges.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Glass stems on a conveyor belt at Arc International in France. The company needs natural gas to make its glassware, but Europe’s energy crisis has caused gas prices to surge.

item.title: Food Supply Disruption Is Another Front for Russian Falsehoods
item.description: As the war in Ukraine has put pressure on the global markets for food, Russia has spread conspiracy theories that blame the West.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy W. Peters
item.media:description: A farm in Egypt. The country is trying to increase its domestic wheat production as the war in Ukraine has strained supplies of the grain.

item.title: After Hurricane Fiona, Puerto Rico Could Be Without Power For Days
item.description: The storm moved west into the Dominican Republic, as conditions in Puerto Rico remained too dangerous for repair workers early Monday.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: A road flooded by the rains of Hurricane Fiona in Cayey, Puerto Rico, on Sunday.

item.title: In Recovery After Storm, Alaska Faces Hard Days Ahead
item.description: Geography and climate add to the challenges for the hard-hit isolated communities as the cold months draw closer.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schwing
item.media:description: The storm over the weekend was one of the worst to hit Alaska in decades.

item.title: Where 6 Investigations Into Donald Trump Stand
item.description: The former president finds himself without the power of the presidency, staring at a host of prosecutors and lawyers who have him and his associates in their sights.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: Never before has a former president faced an array of federal, state and congressional investigations as extensive as Donald J. Trump has.

item.title: Trial of Trump Adviser Tom Barrack Could Shed Light on Foreign Agents
item.description: Thomas Barrack, a Los Angeles private equity executive, is accused of working secretly for the United Arab Emirates.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Davis O’Brien
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prosecutors say Thomas Barrack pushed the U.A.E.’s foreign policy wish list onto the Trump administration.

item.title: After Texas Sent Him to Washington, One Migrant Launches a New Life
item.description: Lever Alejos, who was delivered to the nation’s capital courtesy of Gov. Greg Abbott, has found plenty of work. ‘I feel fortunate the governor put me on a bus to Washington.’
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Oliver Contreras for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lever Alejos, 29, is one of a record number of Venezuelans crossing the southern border into the United States, seeking asylum and hoping to build permanent lives in America.

item.title: Inflation Remains Voters’ Top Concern. Can Republicans Keep Their Focus?
item.description: Democrats and Republicans are running parallel campaigns, with one party emphasizing abortion and democracy, the other inflation and the economy — and both talking past each other.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman
item.media:description: Senators Lindsey Graham, Bill Cassidy, John Barrasso and John Thune at an August news conference opposing Democrats’ energy and drug pricing bill.

item.title: Railroads’ Strategy Thrilled Wall Street, but Not Customers and Workers
item.description: Freight railways pushed to streamline their operations and improve their profit margins. Critics say the approach left the system stretched thin.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi and Peter Eavis
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
item.media:description: The freight rail industry reinvented itself through decades of consolidation and a quest for efficiency.

item.title: Las Vegas Aces Beat Sun for First WNBA Championship
item.description: The Aces shook off their reputation for being better in the regular season by holding off several rallies by the Sun.
item.dc:creator: Kris Rhim
item.media:description: A'ja Wilson, the franchise player of the Las Vegas Aces, celebrating winning the W.N.B.A. championship on Sunday.

item.title: Life Is Hazardous for Urban Raptors. These Women Offer Hope.
item.description: Injured birds of prey have a fighting chance to recover thanks to the volunteers at Owl Moon Raptor Center in Boyds, Md.
item.dc:creator: Jules Jacobs

item.title: You Cannot Be Too Cynical About Trump (or His Imitators)
item.description: The former president has company in the nether regions.
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
item.media:credit: Matt Cosby for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers and migrants in Edgartown, Mass.

item.title: At Summer’s End, a Moment of Wild Surprise
item.description: As equinox nears, the lovely cycle life is happening just behind the place in my garden where the goldenrod and the asters look so beautiful together.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Renkl

item.title: Gina McCarthy: Businesses No Longer See Climate Action as Driving Job Losses
item.description: The private sector now sees climate as an opportunity for job creation and economic revitalization.
item.dc:creator: Gina McCarthy
item.media:credit: Sarah Blesener for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gina McCarthy at the Natural Resources Defense Council in 2020.

item.title: A More Inclusive Global Order Is Possible
item.description: As the world transitions to recovery from the pandemic, the inequities are only widening, both between and within countries.
item.dc:creator: Darren Walker
item.media:description: A protest last year about making the Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine more accessible to poor countries.

item.title: What Joe Biden Knows That No One Expected Him To
item.description: A liberalism that is as ambitious about solving problems through invention as it is through redistribution would be powerful indeed.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein
item.category: Advanced Research Projects Agency for Health
item.media:credit: Illustration by Frank Augugliaro; Photograph by EyeEm/Getty Images

item.title: Math Is the Great Secret
item.description: If human beings invented numbers and counting, then how is it that there are numbers such as primes that have attributes no one gave them?
item.dc:creator: Alec Wilkinson

item.title: The Return of Combat Joe
item.description: President Biden’s combative side comes out periodically. That’s when he’s at his best.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow

item.title: Our Memory Is Flawed. Luckily, God’s Isn’t.
item.description: What a parent’s dementia reveals about God and humanity.
item.dc:creator: Tish Harrison Warren

item.title: Democracy Challenged
item.description: Representative government faces its most serious threats in decades.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Kahn

item.title: Can the U.K. Remain United Without the Queen?
item.description: Over her 70-year reign, the monarch helped bind the four nations of the United Kingdom together. Her death heralds a period of greater uncertainty for that union.
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Diana Nguyen, Stella Tan, Mooj Zadie, Michael Simon Johnson, Rachel Quester, Paige Cowett, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Waiting to pay respects to Queen Elizabeth II on Thursday. The line stretched for some five miles and officials said at one point that it could take 24 hours to reach the monarch’s coffin.

item.title: What Does Queen Elizabeth’s Death Mean for Canada?
item.description: The accession of King Charles III may inspire more discussion about the relevance of the monarchy in Canada, but materially, experts say it’s business as usual.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: King Charles III accompanied the procession taking Queen Elizabeth II’s coffin to Westminster Hall.

item.title: After Dobbs: Does ‘Big Tent’ Feminism Exist? Should It?
item.description: Anne-Marie Slaughter and Tressie McMillan Cottom on the future of the feminist movement.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Argument’

item.title: Clearview AI, Used by Police to Find Criminals, Now in Public Defenders’ Hands
item.description: After a Florida man was accused of vehicular homicide, his lawyer used Clearview AI’s facial recognition software to prove his innocence. But other defense lawyers say Clearview’s offer rings hollow.
item.dc:creator: Kashmir Hill
item.category: National Assn of Criminal Defense Lawyers
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: The police believed Andrew Grantt Conlyn had been driving during a car crash that killed his friend. Facial recognition software helped find the man who knew he had been in the passenger’s seat.

item.title: How Russian Trolls Helped Keep the Women’s March Out of Lock Step
item.description: As American feminists came together in 2017 to protest Donald Trump, Russia’s disinformation machine set about deepening the divides among them.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry

item.title: Maximilian Lerner, Whose Espionage Skills Helped Win a War, Dies at 98
item.description: An Austrian immigrant, he was one of the so-called Ritchie Boys, who were trained at a secret Army intelligence camp to serve in World War II.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: How to Prepare for Flu Season
item.description: We may be more susceptible to the virus than we have been in recent years, but doctors have tips to stay healthy.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer

item.title: How to Nurse a Vulnerability Hangover
item.description: That thing you shared last night? It’s probably just fine.
item.dc:creator: Holly Burns

item.title: What Parents Should Know About Enterovirus: Symptoms and Risks
item.description: The C.D.C. has issued an alert about enterovirus D68, which has been linked to rare, polio-like paralysis.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Kayana Szymczak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children who experience paralysis after contracting enterovirus, like this 4-year-old boy, may need physical therapy to help rebuild strength and balance.

item.title: How Family and Friends Helped Get Me Through the Pandemic
item.description: As Covid raged, many Americans hunkered down with family members and relied on friends — and some came away with deepened relationships. Here are a few of their stories.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Needelman
item.media:credit: Cig Harvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rita and Jon Ellis at Lermond Pond in Maine. Mr. Ellis credits his wife for his recovery from pancreatic cancer. They are two of the many people who leaned on family and friends to help them through a difficult couple of years.

item.title: Are monkeypox scars permanent?
item.description: The best time to care for skin lesions is in their active phase.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh

item.title: Bharti Kher’s Multi-Headed Goddess Statue Arrives at Central Park
item.description: A multi-headed mother figure by the sculptor Bharti Kher has arrived at Central Park. Its message is open to interpretation — and comfortable with contradiction.
item.dc:creator: Siddhartha Mitter
